loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is 40 years old and has two children. Marife is married and has two children who are in school.

Marife is in the agricultural business of pig fattening in the Philippines. Marife requested a loan of 20,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy feed, vitamins, and other supplies for her business.

Marife has been in the business of pig fattening for 15 years now, and has borrowed 7 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins, and other supplies for her business.

loans.name: Henry Antonio

texts.es: Don Henry de 47 años de edad, habita en Juigalpa Chontales, labora para la Alcaldía de Juigalpa, actualmente esta separado de de su esposa, esta a cargo de su hijo en edad escolar el cual se lo cuida su mama.  Con sacrificio ha ido mejorando las condiciones en su vivienda, cambiando el techo poco a poco, pero no ha logrado cambiarlo en su totalidad, por lo que desea comprar Zing, Perlin, Golosos y pagar mano de obra y así realizar esta inversión de cambiar el Zin en la parte posterior de la Vivienda, el cual esta en mal estado provocando que cuando llueve se moje la parte de adentro de su vivienda.  Con esta mejora estará garantizando  las condiciones habitacional en su hogar.
texts.en: Henry, 47, lives in Juigalpa, Chontales.  He works for Juigalpa city hall.  He’s currently separated from his wife.  Henry’s mother cares for his school-age son.  He’s been improving his home with much sacrifice.  He’s been gradually replacing the roof but hasn’t succeeded in replacing it completely which is why he wants to buy metal sheets, purlins, screws and to pay labor costs to replace the metal sheeting in the rear of the house which is in bad shape and lets rainwater inside that wets the interior of the house.  This improvement will ensure living conditions at home.

loans.use: to buy building supplies to replace the roof.

loans.name: Elias

texts.es:
Elias es de la ciudad de Curuguaty, es estudiante y trabaja a la vez, también comenta que está siguiendo la carrera de contabilidad. El comenta que su meta es ser un buen profesional, y que pueda ayudar a su familia por medio de su trabajo.
Le gusta mucho la carrera que está estudiando, ya que le permitirá abrirse muchas puertas y desarrollarse como persona y profesional, es por eso que está poniendo todo su empeño. Agradece por la oportunidad que está recibiendo que le será de mucha ayuda.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en el pago de las cuotas de su universidad, y de esa forma poder seguir estudiando y luchando por convertirse en una gran profesional.
texts.en:
Elías is from the city of Curuguaty.  He’s a student and works at the same time.  He also comments that he’s majoring in Accounting.  He comments that his goal is to become a good professional who can help his family by means of his work.

He likes the career he’s studying very much for it will allow him to open many doors and to develop as a person and a professional; this is why he’s putting his maximum effort into it.  He’s grateful for the opportunity he’s getting for it will be of much help.

He’s asking for this loan to be able to pay university tuition and fees to continue with his studies and striving to become a great professional.

loans.use: to pay university tuition and fees.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a very hardworking lady from Nakuru. She is 23 years old, not yet married but taking care of one child, age 4 years.

She is in the business of beauty salon, which she has been carrying out for the last 3 years. To enable her to buy an extra hair drier to be used on customers who visit her salon, she has applied for her first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET Ltd.

Her monthly income right now is KES 15,000, and she plans to use the profits from her expanded business to buy a blow drier, some hair chemicals, and some weaves.

She hopes that in the future, she will open a hair and beauty college.

loans.use: to buy a hair drier to be used on customers who visit her salon.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel has a retail business in Makueni town. He sells household goods such as water buckets, jugs and plates. He is 36 years old and is married to Mary. They have one child. Ezekiel has been in the business for 5 years and he makes a monthly income of KES 35,200.

This is his  third loan term and he plans to use the amount to buy more stock of household goods to sell. These include plates, cups, water jugs and buckets, cooking pans, stoves and lamps. He anticipates to make more profits, with which he will expand his business and educate his child.

In the future, Ezekiel hopes to own his own business building.

loans.use: to buy more household goods to sell.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 50 years old, widowed, and mother of four adult children. She has a business of selling cloths in Naivasha, which she has been running for five years. Lucy has applied for her second loan, from Kadet Ltd., to enable her to purchase additional stock of cloths and curtains. With the anticipated profit, she plans to open a boutique.

In the near future, Lucy hopes to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy cloths and curtains.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris has a beauty salon business, and has been running it for the last 2 years. She also sells beauty products, and it has been profitable. She is 31 years old and a single mother of one child. 

Having paid all her previous loans successfully, this will be her fourth loan term, and she plans to use the amount to buy hair shampoos, towels, hair oils, and nail polish for use in her salon. This will enable her to serve her clients well and generate more profits, with which she will use to educate her child.

In future, Damaris hopes and dreams of having her own house.

loans.use: to buy shampoos, towels, hair oils, and nail polish.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a single woman with two children; both attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past ten years, Mwanajuma has operated a retail shop business, selling items to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge in her business and she dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, cooking oil to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is 60 years old and married. She has six children. 

Milagros is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Milagros has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 30 years now, and has borrowed 7 times in the past, from NWTF, to sustain her business.

Milagros would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is 27 years old. He is single and has been in the business for the past two years. With the loan, he would like to buy more retail items such as saucepans, soap and cooking oil for sale. The profits from the business will be used for savings and to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more saucepans, soap and cooking oil for sale.

loans.name: Rheami

texts.en:
Rheami is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 21,000 through NWTF to buy more items to sell like snack foods, juice, coffee, milk, canned goods, soft drinks, etc. in her general store.

Rheami has been in this business for three years. She earns more income from motorcycle transport.

Rheami has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like snack foods, juice, coffee, milk, canned goods, soft drinks, etc. in her general store

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman, and has been blessed with four kids who attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She operated a fish selling business, which has been operational for over one year. In addition, she operates a cafe to supplement her income. She mentioned seasonality as a challenge in the business, and she dreams of becoming a wholesaler of fish in the future. 

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase sacks of fish for resale. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fish for resale.

loans.name: Vita

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Vita works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling food supplements in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from motorcycle transport. Vita is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock of food supplements to sell to her customers for her business buying and selling food supplements.

Vita has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of food supplements to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 40 years old, married to Evans and together they are blessed with three children aged 20, 18 and 16 years old.

She has a timber business in Naivasha that she has been running for 15 years with an average monthly income of KSH 14,000. She has applied for her second loan from Kadet Ltd to enable her to purchase timber for sale. With the anticipated profit, she plans to open another timber yard.

In the near future, she hopes her business will grow and her children will be well educated.

loans.use: To purchase timber to sell

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josphine is 41 years old, married and together they are blessed with three children who are in school.

She has a charcoal business in Naivasha that she has been running for four years with an average monthly income of KSH 40,000. Josphine has applied for her first loan with Kadet Ltd. to purchase more charcoal for sale. With the anticipated profit, she plans to open another charcoal business.

In the near future, she hopes to see her business grow and be financially stable.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is a very hardworking lady from Nyahururu. She is 34 years old and married to Peter who produces some additional income for the family. They are blessed with three children who are 14, 12 and 7 years old.

She is into the business of selling fruits and vegetables including tomatoes, fruits and other vegetables, which she has been doing for the past four years.

To enable her to add more stock of these items, she has applied for her first loan of KSHS 20,000 from Kadet Ltd.

Her monthly income right now is KSHS 16,000 and she hopes to use the anticipated profits from her expanded business to educate her children and to further expand her business.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to have a successful life and business.

loans.use: To buy more fruits, tomatoes and other vegetables to sell

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 35 years old from Olkalou. He is married to Mercy, who assists him in farming, and they are blessed with two children, ages 15 and 11 years old.

He is a farmer who practices mixed farming, e.g. growing of crops, such as maize, beans, wheat and potatoes, and keeping livestock, such as cows and goats. He has been in this business for the last five years. 

To enable him be more productive, he has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Kadet Ltd., which shall be used to buy a heifer and pay laborers who work in his farm.

His monthly income right now is KES 20,000, and he hopes to use the profits from his expanded business to pay his loan to Kadet Ltd. and educate his children.

In the future, charles hopes to buy a piece of land on which he will specialize in modern dairy farming

loans.use: to buy a heifer and pay laborers working in his farm.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 46 years old, married to Tecla and they have been blessed with two children (aged 10 and 14 years). Joseph is a poultry farmer and has been in this business for four years with a current monthly income of KES 20,000.

Joseph is borrowing KES 50,000 in order  to expand his business. He plans to increase his animal stock with the anticipated profit. This is his second loan, after successfully paying back his previous loan.

loans.use: to expand his business.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 40 years old. He is a father of four children, between nine and sixteen years of age. 

With the loan, Joseph would like to buy more flour and cups as well as plates to be used in his mini restaurant. He has spent two years in his business. The profits from the business will be used to make more savings.

loans.use: to buy more flour for using in the bakery, cups and plates for use in the business.

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Melodina works hard to support her family. Melodina is married, and she has a business making furniture in the Philippines.

She has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional materials like wood, paint, paint brushes, nails, etc., for her business.

Melodina has been in this business for 20 years now.  She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials like wood, paint, paint brushes, nails, etc., for her business

loans.name: Juan Pablo

texts.es: Juan es un hombre emprendedor y dinámico que decidió hace algunos años iniciar su propio negocio, idea que surgió de la necesidad de generar los recursos económicos por cuenta propia, pues se le hacía difícil encontrar oportunidades de empleo por la alta demanda que existe en el país. Por esta razón montó un pequeño almacén de accesorios para celulares y alquiler de películas, trabaja solo todos los días de la semana, de 8:00 am a 7:00 pm y ofrece accesorios de celulares, recargas, cargadores, presta el servicio de reparación y además alquila películas en DVD, de esta manera obtiene el dinero suficiente para aportar a la economía de su hogar. Juan aprendió la actividad de un familiar que le enseñó a desenvolverse en el campo de los negocios, especialmente de telefonía móvil. Su negocio ha dado buenos resultados y poco a poco ha ido aumentando sus ventas, esto lo motiva a seguir buscando alternativas para seguir avanzando, por ello, solicita el séptimo ciclo de crédito con el que desea comprar una vitrina de exhibición y mercancía al por mayor (equipos móviles, películas, recargas, protectores de pantalla, carcasas, entre otros), de esta manera tendrá la posibilidad de mostrar mejor los productos que ofrece y además tendrá un inventario más variado para satisfacer los gustos y requerimientos de sus clientes, lo que se reflejará en el incremento notable de las ventas y los ingresos generados por estas. Juan con su espíritu luchador y su entusiasmo desea seguir fortaleciendo su negocio y sueña con adquirir un local mucho más grande para ampliar su negocio y combinarlo con una sala de internet, así prestará un servicio integrado y en un mismo lugar, logrando atraer más clientes y mejorando la entrada de recursos económicos con los que podrá dar una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Juan’s an enterprising, dynamic man who decided a few years ago to open his own business.  The idea arose from the need to generate income of his own for he was finding it difficult to find employment because of the high demand for jobs in the country.  Because of this, he opened a small store where he sells mobile phone accessories and rents movies.  He works alone every day of the week from 8am until 7pm.  He sells mobile phone accessories, air time recharges, chargers and also provides repair services.  He also rents movie DVDs earning enough money this way to contribute to household support.

Juan learned the activity from a family member who taught him how to manage in business especially in the mobile phone area.  His business has had good results and his sales have gradually increased.  This motivates him to continue seeking alternatives to continue making progress.

This is why he’s requesting his 7th loan that he will use to buy a display case and merchandise at wholesale (mobile phones, movies, chargers, screen protectors, cases, etc.) in order to better display his goods and to have a more varied inventory of products on-hand to satisfy his customers’ needs and wants which will lead to a significant increase in sales and in income generated by them.

With his warrior spirit and enthusiasm, Juan intends to continue strengthening his small business and dreams with acquiring a larger locale to expand the business and combine it with an Internet café to provide an integrated service in the same place succeeding in attracting more customers improving his income to provide better quality of life for his family.

loans.use: to buy a display case and merchandise.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is widowed and has five young children who go to school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over four years, Halima has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women. She cites seasonality as her major challenge and she dreams of establishing a boutique in the near future.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase fabric and threads for her sewing business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth material and sewing threads for her business.

loans.name: Faida

texts.en:
Faida operates a kiosk, selling bread, sweets, biscuits, etc. She earns additional income selling charcoal. 

Faida is requesting another loan for 50,000 KES, which she will use to to purchase biscuits, bread, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and cooking oil for her business.  With the loan, she hopes to improve her business. Faida feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which has allowed her to maintain her level of profits and help her family cover their personal expenses

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, bread, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and cooking oil

loans.name: Ricaute De Jesús

texts.es: Ricaute es un padre de familia que desde hace varios años se dedica a la actividad de fundición de metales como cobre y aluminio, actividad que realiza desde su propio taller ubicado en el occidente de la ciudad donde reside y donde se ha dado a conocer realizando su labor. De esta forma ha logrado sacar adelante a su familia, conformada por su esposa y 3 hijos, por los cuales lucha incansablemente para darles una buena educación y bienestar.  Actualmente solicita el crédito para comprar un molino de metales, con el que podrá reducir  los costos de producción, ya que él mismo podrá moler el cobre y el aluminio para luego fundirlo y no tendrá que seguir pagando por este servicio, además mejorará las condiciones de trabajo; así mejorará notablemente la entrada de recursos económicos para solventar las necesidades de su familia y podrá seguir avanzando para llegar a cumplir su mayor deseo que es acreditar bien su negocio y adquirir más molinos para poder aumentar la producción.  De esta forma Ricaute tendrá la oportunidad de generar una estabilidad económica favorable, que según él, es indispensable para que las cosas del hogar funcionen correctamente, logrando que sus hijos tengan una excelente educación, un mejor bienestar y calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Ricaute’s a father who has worked for several years smelting metals like copper and aluminum.  He does this in his own workshop located in the western part of the city where he lives and where he’s become well-known doing this work.  He’s managed to support his family consisting of his wife and three children this way.  He strives for them unceasingly to provide them with a good education and well-being.

He’s asking for this loan at present to buy a metal grinder to reduce his production costs because he will be able to grind the copper and aluminum himself to then smelt it; he will no longer have to pay for this service and he will also improve his working conditions thus significantly improving his income to meet family needs and continue making progress to reach his greatest dream which is to prove his business’ worth and to acquire more mills to be able to increase production.  In this way, Ricaute will be able to generate favorable economic stability which, according to him, is indispensable so that things at home will function correctly succeeding in providing an excellent education for his children, improved well-being and quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a metal grinder.

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer is 44 years old and married. She has been blessed with four children, aged 23, 20,18 and 12 years. She is a tailor, and she has been in business for 14 years. Right now, her monthly income from the business is KES 25,000.  She is borrowing a loan of KES 30,000. She intends to use it to purchase materials to make sofa cushion covers, commonly referred to as "vitambas."

Jeniffer plans to pay back her loan with the anticipated revenues. This is her second loan. Her hope and dream is to expand her business and to create employment opportunities for others.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make sofa cushion covers

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe TIESSIRI ont en moyenne  34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à  KOUROUBADOUGOU un des villages dans le cercle de SAN de la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente graines.
 Apres avoir correctement remboursés les prêts précédents en prêt de campagne,  les femmes du groupe TIESSIRI sont à leur 1 er   prêt solidaire. KARIA MPERE 1ere femme  à debout à  droite sur la photo  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  un sac de 100kgs  des graines d’arachide et 100kgs de mil. Elles s’approvisionnent KROUBADOUGOU et les villages environnants. Elles effectuent ses ventes, sur place à KOUROUBADOUGOU et KIMPARANA pendant les jours de foires, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, et l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Tiessiri group are on average 34 years old with four children. They all live in traditional extended families in Kouroubadougou,  which is one of the villages in the San circle of the fourth administrative region of Mali.
These women met through family ties and do business in the buying and selling of seeds.
Having correctly repaid their previous seasonal loans, the women of the Tiessiri group request their first solidarity loan. Karia Mpere, who is the first woman standing on the right in the photo, plans to use her loan to buy a bag of 100 kilograms of groundnut seeds and 100 kilograms of millet. They buy their supplies in Kroubadougou and in the surrounding villages. They sell their goods at Kouroubadougou and Kimparana on market days to a clientele made up of both men and women for cash and often for credit.
They plan to make an average monthly profit of 15 000FCFA which they will use for expenses relative to health, food, clothing and school fees and the remainder will be reinvested in their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase millet and groundnut seeds.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 50 years old and has a live-in partner. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Juliet has a vegetables and spices business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 20000 loan, through NWTF, to buy more vegetables and spices to sell in her stall.

Juliet has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, Juliet would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and spices to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Gritta

texts.en:
Gritta is 29 years old. She is married and has two children, aged between five and eight. She has been selling locally made beer from sorghum for the past three years. 

With the loan, Gritta would like to buy more sorghum to make more locally produced beers for sale. The profits from the business will be used to make savings.

loans.use: to buy more sorghum for making local beers.

loans.name: Gerondia

texts.en:
Gerondia works hard to support her family. Gerondia is married, and she has a general store business in the Philippines.

She has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like shampoo, laundry soap, coffee, soft drinks, sugar, etc., to sell.

Gerondia has been in this business for 10 years now.  She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like shampoo, laundry soap, coffee, soft drinks, sugar, etc., to sell

loans.name: Merla

texts.en:
Merla is 53 years old and married, with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Merla has a buy-and-sell ready-to-wear business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy more stocks of ready-to-wear to sell, like shorts, t-shirts, blouses, and pants.

Merla has been in this business for three years. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of ready-to-wear to sell, like shorts, t-shirts, blouses, and pants.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is married, with seven children, and all her children go to school.  She also take care of an additional family member (sister). 

She has a business selling charcoal, and she has been in this business for 20 years. 

Agnes has applied for a loan of UGX 1,300,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She generates additional income from dry cleaning.  

She works from home seven days out of every week and sells to all categories of people, but at retail six days out of every week.  Her major business challenges include thieves and seasonality.   

She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to build rental rooms. 

She resides in her family house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water.    Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina works hard to support her family. Merlina is married and has a direct-selling Natasha products business in the Philippines.

Merlina requested a PHP 17,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy additional stocks of Natasha products to sell, like body spray, lotion, body soap, and blouses.

Merlina has been in this business for three years now. In the future, she would like to save enough money, so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of Natasha products to sell, like body spray, lotion, body soap, and blouses.

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe SOUTOURA ont en moyenne  34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à  KOUROUBADOUGOU un des villages dans le cercle de SAN de la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente graines.
 Après avoir correctement remboursés les prêts précédents en prêt de campagne,  les femmes du groupe SOUTOURA sont à leur 1 er   prêt solidaire. ROUTHE 1ere femme  à gauche   sur la photo  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  un sac de 100kgs  des graines d’arachide et 100kgs de mil. Elles s’approvisionnent KOUROUBADOUGOU et les villages environnants. Elles effectuent ses ventes, sur place à KOUROUBADOUGOU et KIMPARANA pendant les jours de foires, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, et l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Soutoura group are on average 34 years old with 4 children, and they all live in traditional larger families in Kouroubadougou, one of the villages in San, the fourth administrative region of Mali. The women came to know each other through family and are in the business of selling seeds. Their previous individual loans having been fully repaid, the women of the Soutoura group are now on their first group loan together.

Routhe, pictured as the first woman on the left in the photo, plans to use her loan to purchase a 100-kg bag of peanut seeds and a 100-kg bag of millet. The women stock up in Kouroubadougou and the neighboring villages, and then sell their products at markets in Kouroubadougou and Kimparana during festival days to a customer base made up of both men and women, sometimes for cash and often on credit.

The women hope to earn an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA which they will use to care for their health expenses, food, clothing, schooling, and the remainder to reinvest in their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase millet and peanut seeds

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 25 years old, married and has one child. Jean works very hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional inventory to sell in her general store. Jean has been in this business for 12 years and sells a variety of items such as bread, shampoo, soy sauce, vinegar, cooking oil, canned goods, etc. 

In the future, Jean would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Fabio

texts.es: Fabio llegó a la ciudad donde vive actualmente, siendo una víctima más del desplazamiento forzado, debido a la violencia que se presentó en su pueblo natal hace más de una década. Se trasladó dejando atrás todo lo que había construido con esfuerzo, como su negocio de comidas rápidas que llevaba varios años en funcionamiento y estaba bien acreditado, sin embargo, ha sabido sobrepasar los obstáculos y con entusiasmo, empeño y mucho amor, ha logrado salir adelante; hoy en día, a sus 40 años de edad, tiene una pequeña cafetería ubicada en la casa donde vive, en un pequeño espacio que adecuó; allí ha logrado generar los ingresos suficientes para sobrevivir. Actualmente solicita el crédito para invertirlo en un nuevo proyecto productivo, pues con el dinero desea comprar un carro de comidas rápidas y los insumos que requiere (panes, carnes frías, salsas, gaseosas, entre otros), así desea complementar sus ingresos, aprovechando la experiencia que posee en este campo laboral y podrá ofrecer un mejor servicio, incluyendo nuevos productos que satisfagan los gustos de sus clientes y, a la vez le permitirá incrementar sus ventas y las ganancias que percibe por su labor. Para Fabio, todo esto se traduce en el mejoramiento de economía, logrando una estabilidad que le permitirá disfrutar de mejor calidad de vida, lo que se ha convertido en su deseo más inmediato.
texts.en:
Fabio arrived in the city he currently lives in as a victim of forced displacement due to the violence occurring in his native town a decade ago.  He moved leaving everything he’d built with so much effort, like the well-known fast-food business he’d had for several years, behind.  Nevertheless, he’s learned to overcome obstacles with enthusiasm, effort and much love.  He’s managed to move forward and today, at the age of 40, he has a small home-based café set up in a small space he equipped.  He’s succeeded in generating enough income there to survive.

He’s currently asking for the loan to invest in a new productive project.  He wants to use the money to buy a fast-food cart and ingredients he needs (bread rolls, cold-cuts, sauces and soft-drinks, among others) to earn extra income taking advantage of the experience he has in this line of work.  He will be able to offer better service including new products to meet customer demand while at the same time increase sales and profits earned from his labor.  For Fabio, all this will mean an improvement in his economy attaining stability that will allow him to enjoy better quality of life which has become his most pressing dream.

loans.use: to buy a fast-food cart and ingredients.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a single mother of two children, and both her children go to school.  She also takes care of an additional family member (mother). 

She has a business selling onions and tomatoes.  She has been in this business for two years. 

Rose has applied for a loan of UGX 600,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more baskets of onions and tomatoes.  She generates additional income from selling green-banana fingers.   

She works at the market six days out of every week and sells wholesale only. Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. 

She aspires to own a delivery van to ease in transportation and also to build her own house.  

She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expense includes school fees, rent, and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is married. She has five children, three of whom go to school. She doesn’t have to take care of any additional family members. 

Eva has a retail shop and has been in this business for 2 years. She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDTSACCO to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of soap, loaves of bread and cooking oil.  She generates additional income through roasting maize.  Eva works in her shop six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only.  Her major business challenges include thieves, defaulters and transportation costs.  She is aspiring to become a wholesaler and also to build her own house. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of soap, loaves of bread and cooking oil.

loans.name: Stellamaris

texts.en:
Stellamaris works as a poultry farmer in Makueni town. She sells and supplies both chicken and eggs, and the business has been profitable for the last 9 years. She is 40 years old and married with two children. As well as the poultry farming business, she is also a fruit vendor.

Stellamaris will use this loan to buy more chickens for rearing, thereby increasing her stock, and also to buy more poultry feeds. She will also buy more oranges and bananas for selling in her fruit business. She will use the profits that are generated to educate her children.

Stellamaris hopes to own a plot of land in the near future.

loans.use: To buy more chicken and poultry feed for her poultry farm, and to buy more fruit to sell.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia is 51 years old and married. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan, through NWTF, to purchase more goods to sell like snack foods, canned goods, noodles, detergent soap, coffee and other groceries for her general store.

Eugenia has borrowed and repaid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and earns additional income from food vending.

Eugenia aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell like snack foods, canned goods, noodles, detergent soap, coffee and other groceries for her general store.

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en:
Hanna is a widowed mother of two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity, nor piped water. 

Hanna has operated a kiosk business from home for the past two years, selling to passersby and neighbors. In addition, she does farming as her other source of income. She cited seasonality and theft as challenges in the business. 

With the KES 15,000 loan, Hanna wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana is a mother with children She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She has operated a kiosk business from home for the past two years, selling household consumables to passersby and neighbors. In addition she does farming as her other source of income. She cited theft as a challenge in the business. 

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, and rice to sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina lives in the Litein area of Kenya. She has four children and has been operating a farm for five years. Her primary income sources are milk and crops.

She stated that horticulture is what she finds most enjoyable about farming. Her biggest challenge is lack of enough funds. One of the animals on the farm has been given the name Tuyai.

When Regina was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, she replied, "because of the grace period." During Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, she learned that they offer several products, not only dairy cows.

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how the loan will benefit her family, Regina said it would help her to pay school fees for her children.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Regina owns a cow, but she does not own a pig, poultry, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. Regina has in her household a mosquito net, but she does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV, or a DVD player.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rodrigo Andrés

texts.es: Rodrigo, con 27 años de edad, se dedica a manejar su propio negocio, un pequeño puesto de venta de bombones de pollo que se encuentra ubicado a las afueras de un café bar de un amigo, en el parque principal del municipio donde reside. El proyecto inició cuando su amigo le ofreció en arrendamiento el espacio, pues él se encargaría de la administración del café bar y, a él le gustó la idea y comenzó a buscar la receta para preparar sus ya conocidos bombones de pollo, pero el desafío más grande que se le presentó fue tener que pagar un millón de pesos por esta receta, a pesar de las dificultades económicas que tenía, él pudo completar el dinero y finalmente comenzó su negocio, obteniendo tan buenos resultados que a los dos meses de funcionamiento, ya había librado la inversión que había hecho. Hoy en día ya lleva 9 meses dedicándose a esta labor, trabaja de lunes a jueves de 2:00 a 10:00 pm y los fines de semana de 8:00 am a 10:00 pm, además cuenta con el apoyo de un hermano. Solicita el crédito para agrandar su negocio, pues desea comprar un carro de comidas rápidas, una vitrina, utensilios de cocina e insumos al por mayor (panes, carnes frías, aceite, salsas, gaseosas, entre otros), así tendrá la posibilidad de ampliar su portafolio de productos y podrá atraer nuevos clientes, pues tendrá la posibilidad de ofrecer nuevos productos y así satisfacer los gustos diversos de sus comensales, dando como resultado un incremento notable en las ventas y en los ingresos que obtiene día a día.  Rodrigo, sabe que requiere trabajar con mucha disciplina, orden y esfuerzo para lograr los objetivos que se propone, además sueña con fortalecer y hacer crecer más su negocio y en un futuro poder montar nuevas sucursales, lo que para él significa tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Rodrigo, 27, runs his own business, a small food stand selling well-known chicken nuggets located outside a friend’s café-bar in the municipal park in the city where he lives.  The project started when his friend offered to rent him the space since he would manage the café-bar.  He liked the idea and started looking for the recipe to make the well-known chicken nuggets.  But the greatest challenge he faced was having to pay one-million pesos for the recipe.  Despite his economic difficulties he was able to gather the money together to pay for the recipe and finally start his business.  He had such good results that after just two months in operation he was able to recoup his investment.  

Today, he’s been in business nine months working Monday to Thursday from 2-10pm and from 8am to 10pm on weekends.  A brother helps him.

He’s asking for the loan to expand the business.  He wants to buy a fast-food cart, a display case, kitchen utensils and ingredients at wholesale (bread rolls, cold-cuts, oil, sauces, soft-drinks, among others) to expand his menu of products to attract new customers for he’ll be able to offer new products satisfying new customers with the new products he’ll have on sale.  Result will be significant sales and daily income increase.

Rodrigo knows that he must work with much discipline, order and effort to reach the objectives he’s set.  He also dreams with strengthening and expanding the business so that in future he can open new branches which will mean a significant improvement in his quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a fast-food cart and ingredients.

loans.name: 04-07-01-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yên has a retail business selling coal. She is asking for a loan to buy coal to resell. Yên is 47 years old, and she is married with 2 children. Yên is the group leader of the 04-07-01-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with 2 dependents.

In 2005, Yên joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Yên has successfully repaid five loans from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Yên has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main problem that Yên faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Yên hopes for her children to find good jobs, for her family to be healthy and happy and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to buy coal to resell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is married. All five of her children go to school. She doesn’t have to take care of any additional family members. She has a business of retail shop and has been in this business for many years. 

Judith has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more sugar, salt, boxes of soap, rice and pans of bread. She works in a shop and sells on retail basis, six days out of every week. Her major business challenges include thieves, transportation costs and defaulters. She is aspiring to own a fully stocked retail shop and also to build her own house. 

Judith resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, boxes of soap, rice and pans of bread.

loans.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo is married. Her two children attend school. She doesn’t have to take care of any additional family members. 

Teo has a business of selling shoes. She has been in this business for 4 years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used shoes. She works at the market and sells, on a retail basis, six days out of every week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She is aspiring to become a wholesaler and also to build her own house. 

Teo resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used shoes.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is a very prominent farmer from Olkalou. She is 51 years old, not married, but a mother of three children, aged 24, 21 and 17 years. 

Christina is a farmer who specializes in wheat farming and other food crops. To enable her to buy fertilizer and herbicides for control of weeds in her farm and to ensure maximum yields, Christina has applied for her second loan of Kshs. 20,000 from Kadet Ltd.

Her monthly income right now is is  Kshs.10,000 and she plans to use profits from her expanded business to pay school fees for those of her children whom are still schooling and for paying her loan to Kadet Ltd.

She hopes that in the future her standard of living will be better.

loans.use: To buy farm  inputs like fertilizer and herbicides to control weeds in her wheat farm

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is 44 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. Rosalinda runs a general store in the Philippines, and has asked for a 22,000 Philippines Pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store.

Rosalinda has borrowed and successfully repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her general store for 18 years, and also earns additional income from selling pre-paid mobile phone credits.

Rosalinda dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Emiliana

texts.en:
Emiliana is a married woman with children. She lives at a rental house that has piped water and electricity. She cites food being her greatest monthly expense.

She has operated a beauty salon business and her potential customers are her fellow neighbours and people at the market place. She dreams of earning more income and incorporating hairdressing skills in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase chemicals and hair conditioners for her beauty salon business. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals and hair conditioners for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is married and has four children, two of whom are in school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and feeding the family. 

She sells charcoal on a retail basis.  She has been in this business for eight years. She works six days a week.  She gets additional income from rental houses. 

She has applied for a loan of Uganda shillings 500,000 from MCDT-SACCO. She will use the funds to buy more bags of charcoal to sell. Her major business challenges include seasonality (rainy season), which hinders her movements and transportation. She aspires to get a van for transporting her charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: 04-07-07-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngát has a retail business selling dry food. She is asking for a loan to buy dry food to resell.

Ngát is 53 years old and she is married with three children. She is the group leader of the 04-07-07-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of 7 members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with 2 dependents.

In 2005, Ngát joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Ngát has successfully repaid seven loans from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Ngát has been involved in her retail business for five years. The main challenge that Ngát faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With the profits from her business, Ngát hopes for her children to find good jobs, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to buy dry food to resell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
John is 33 years old and is from Olkalou. He is married to Tabitha, who is a farmer, and they are blessed with three children, aged seven, four and one year.

He is a farmer who practices mixed farming; i.e, he grows crops like maize, potatoes, and beans as well as raising livestock like cows, goats and sheep.  John has applied for his fifth loan of Kshs.30,000 from Kadet Ltd. to enable him buy some heifers for raising.  This will help him expand and grow his business tremendously. 

From his sales of farm produce, he makes a monthly income of Kshs.15,000, and he intends to use profits from his expanded business to pay his loan back to Kadet Ltd.  His hope for his future business is to expand his farming activities by indulging in modern farming methods for more productivity.

loans.use: To buy heifers for raising

loans.name: Mike

texts.en:
Mike is 52 years old from Nakuru. He is married to Mary who is a farmer, and they are blessed with four children, aged 15, 12, 9 and 7 years old.

He is in the business of welding, which he has been doing for the last six years. He has applied for his third loan of Kshs.30,000 from Kadet Ltd., which he plans to use to buy welding materials like steel, and gas for use in his business.

Mike's monthly income right now is Kshs. 20,000 and he intends to use the anticipated profits from his expanded business to educate his children.  His hope and dream for his future business is to be the owner of the biggest welding company in his town and for his family to be prosperous.

loans.use: To buy welding materials, like steel, and gas

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a 38-year-old, married man. He has three children with ages ranging from three to eight years. He describes himself to be very focused. 

Daniel operates a retail shop where he sells mobile phone accessories. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are local residents. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy a stock of phone accessories. His business goal is to have several branches within five years. He hopes that, in the future, he will have the best phone accessories shop. 

This is Daniel's first loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance Limited (SMEP DTM).

loans.use: to buy a stock of phone accessories.

loans.name: Noeme

texts.en:
Noeme is a hardworking entrepreneur, who has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 11 years, and she earns more income from a general store.

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF. She will use it to purchase ingredients for her food vending business, like fish, cooking oil, salt, spices, rice, and meat.

Noeme has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money, to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food business, like fish, cooking oil, and spices

loans.name: Joyline

texts.en:
Joyline lives in the Litein area of Kenya. She has one child and has worked as a farmer for nine years.  Her primary income sources are milk, eggs and tea.

Joyline says that the most enjoyable thing about farming is selling her products. Her biggest challenge is insufficient capital. 

Joyline was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, and she said that they had low interest rates. She said that she learnt about savings during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session.

Her highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked 'How will this loan benefit her family?', Joyline replied 'Better living standards.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Joyline owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, electricity' but does not have 'solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.use: To build a green house.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is married and has one child; she goes to school. Zaituni has one additional family member (her mother).

She sells spare parts for cars and motorcycles, at the market. She sells her goods to all kinds of people, on a retail basis. She has been in this business for 10 years. She works seven days a week. She has applied for a loan of Uganda shillings 700,000 from MCDT-SACCO. She will use it to buy more spare parts for motorcycles and car tyres.

Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to build rental houses. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycle spare parts and car tyres, to sell at the market

loans.name: 04-07-02-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hường operates a food stall/restaurant selling fruit. She is asking for a loan to buy fruit to resell. Hường is 31 years old, and she is married with one child. Hường is the group leader of the 04-07-02-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of seven members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a urban area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2005, Hường joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Hường has successfully repaid one loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She has been involved in her business for more than 10 years. The main challenge that Hường faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With the profits from her business Hường hopes to buy land of her own, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to buy fruit to resell

loans.name: Rashida

texts.en: Rashida is a single mother of three children, and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (old parents). She has a business of selling charcoal and has been in this business for seven years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She works at the market six days out of every week and sells on retail basis only. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. Her major business challenges include transportation and thieves. She is aspiring of becoming a wholesaler and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house.  She resides in  a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is married and has four children.  Jenny is 47 years old and lives in Camanse, Sinacaban, Philippines.  She sells nutritious snacks to earn a living and has had this business for ten years. Each month, she earns PHP 1500 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for PHP 6000 to purchase additional ingredients such as breadcrumbs, eggs, mayonnaise, flour, margarine, oil, baking powder, soda, etc.
Jenny has been a member of PMPC for 5 years.  In the future, Jenny hopes to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients such as breadcrumbs, eggs, mayonnaise, flour, margarine, oil, baking powder, soda, etc.

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: Kossiwa est une femme veuve de 54ans avec 3enfants. Elle est revendeuse de produits d’alimentation générale et de pure water dans une boutique. Elle sollicite son premier prêt auprès de WAGES pour acheter et revendre ces produits d’alimentation générale et épargner aussi. Elle espère en devenir une grossiste et avoir une famille aisée. Elle exerce son activité depuis 2000.
texts.en: Kossiwa is a widow aged 54 with three children. She sells foodstuffs and Pure Water in a little shop. She is requesting her first loan from WAGES in order to buy and sell grocery products and be able to put aside savings. She hopes to become a wholesaler and see her family comfortably off. She has been in her business since 2000.

loans.use: to buy and sell grocery products.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a widowed woman with seven children, five of whom are adults and two who are still in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past three years, she has run a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She said that her biggest business challenge is price fluctuation. Mwaka dreams of setting up a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 10,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) loan she wants to buy salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to buy salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Hermina

texts.en:
Hermina 55 years old.  She is married and has four children.  She is a resident of Balamban, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She earns a living through farming and she has been a decade in this business.

She has been a member of PMPC since July 2011 and enjoys the privileges of being a member of the Cooperative. Now she is applying a loan of Php35,000  to buy addtional farm inputs such as seedlings and fertilizers. Through PMPC, her business is now growing.

Hermina deeply wishes to maintain a member in good standing with PMPC.

loans.use: To buy addtional farm inputs such as seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a man of 56 years, married to Margaret and a father of four children, who are all over 18.  He makes soap and detergents in Kangemi; he has been in this business for five years, and gets a monthly income of 20,000 shillings.

This will be Peter's first loan with KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to buy chemicals for making soap and detergent. 

In the future he wants to open a bigger shop.

loans.use: to buy chemicals for making soap and detergents.

loans.name: Felisicima

texts.en:
Felisicima is married and has three children. Felisicima  is 58 years old and lives in Maikay,Tudela, Philippines.
Felisicima is a farmer and grows fruit and vegetable crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for 10 years. She has requested a loan to buy additional fertilizers and other gardening tools, namely, garden leaf blower/vacuum, spade, fork, wheelbarrows, trollies, etc.
Felisicima has been a member of PMPC for eight years. In the future, Felicisima hopes to put up another business that would definitely earn more profit.

loans.use: to buy additional fertilizers and other gardening tools, namely, garden leaf blower/vacuum, spade, fork, wheelbarrows, trollies, etc.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is 32 years old, married, and resident of Doña Josefa, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte, Philippines. Her husband is a tricycle driver. They have three children, all of whom are in school. Starting with capitalization of 8,000PHP, she opened a sari-sari (general store) and was able to expand it with the help of Paglaum Cooperative. Aside from financial assistance, she was able to generate savings and enjoys the benefit given by the co-op. She became a member last September, 2012 ,and has taken out two loans. 

Now she is applying for 35,000PHP to buy additional stock for her sari-sari store, particularly basic commodities. In the future, she wants to own a mini-mart someday, and will be fully satisfied if she sees her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy basic commodities.

location.town: Sindangan - Doña Josefa, Sindangan, Zamboanga del

loans.name: Mouhamadou

texts.fr: Mouhamadou est un jeune homme marié et âgé de 35ans avec un enfant. Il exerce comme profession la cordonnerie depuis 2010 dans son atelier. Il demande son premier prêt auprès de WAGES pour réinvestir dans son activité de cordonnerie. Il envisage créer un nouvel atelier de cochonnerie et assurer l'éducation de son enfant.
texts.en: Mouhamadou is a young married man aged 35 with one child. He has been working as a cobbler since 2010 in his workshop. He is asking for his first loan from WAGES in order to reinvest in his shoe-making business. He hopes to build a new pigpen and ensure the education of his child.

loans.use: to reinvest in his work as a cobbler.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce lives in the Litein area of Kenya. She has four children, and she has been farming for 14 years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, and personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Selling farm products.' Her biggest challenge is 'lack of good markets.' Animals on the farm have been given no names.

Joyce was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Low interest.' This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, and she mentioned the importance of 'developing a savings culture.'

Her highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family,' Joyce replied that the profits will 'give them a better living standard.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Joyce owns cows and poultry, but does not own a pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net and electricity, but does not have solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, or DVD.

loans.use: to construct a greenhouse.

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en:
Dorah is a married mother. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Dorah runs a cereal shop business at the market, selling to passersby and neighbours. She says that seasonality is her major challenge in her business.

With the loan of 50,000 Kenyan Shillings, she wants to buy sacks of maize, beans, rice and sugar. 

Her dream is to see her children get better education and become important people in their society.

loans.use: to buy sacks of maize, beans, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Tei

texts.en:
Tei is a married woman and has been blessed with two kids who attend school. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees. 

Tei has run a poultry selling business for over 2 years. She says that seasonality is her greatest challenge in her business.

With the 15,000 Kenyan Shilling loan, Tei wants to buy poultry feed and more chicks. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy poultry feed and and more chicks.

loans.name: Elvina

texts.en:
Elvina is a married woman, who has six children. Three of them attend school, two are adults, and one is under school age. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and household consumables.

For over two years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store, in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase a stock of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes, onions, and fruit. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes, onions, and fruit

loans.name: Mario De Jesús

texts.es: Mario es un padre de familia de 65 años de edad, que durante 15 años se ha dedicado a trabajar en su propio negocio, una tienda de abarrotes que inició como una opción para generar ingresos y sacar adelante a su familia. El negocio está ubicado en un local propio al lado de su casa, trabaja en compañía de su esposa todos los días de 6:00 am a 8:00 pm. Esta actividad le ha permitido brindar educación a sus 5 hijos, además le dio los recursos para construir un parqueadero y actualmente tiene iniciada la construcción de un apartamento que piensa arrendar para recibir un ingreso adicional. Su empuje, tenacidad y esfuerzo le han permitido lograr todos los objetivos que se propone y manifiesta que a su edad, eso es todo un reto. Actualmente solicita el crédito para comprar surtido al por mayor (granos, pastas, chocolate, dulces, café, mecato, galletería, lácteos, entre otros), así tendrá la posibilidad de aumentar la variedad de su inventario y podrá satisfacer los gustos de sus clientes, aumentando las ventas y como consecuencia, sus ingresos. Mario sueña con poder terminar la construcción que tiene empezada, así complementaría los ingresos y podrá brindar una mejor calidad de vida a su familia, además tendrá la oportunidad de disfrutar al lado de su esposa una vejez más tranquila, sabiendo que dejará un buen legado a sus hijos el día que falte.
texts.en:
Mario is a father aged 65, who has worked in his own business for 15 years. He has a grocery store which started out as a means to make money and support his family. The business is located in a separate premises next to his home, and he works there with his wife every day from 6:00am to 8:00pm. This activity has enabled him to give his five children an education, as well as the money to build a parking area. Work has also begun on building an apartment which he plans to rent out as an additional income. His drive, tenacity and effort have enabled him to achieve all of the goals he sets himself and at his age, that's no easy feat. 

He is now requesting a loan to buy stock in bulk (grains, pastas, chocolate, sweets, coffee, snacks, cakes, dairy products and other items). This will give him the chance to increase the variety of his produce and satisfy his customers' tastes, increasing sales and, thus, his earnings. 

Mario's dream is to finish the construction work he has begun, to supplement his income and offer his family a better quality of life. In addition, he will have the chance to enjoy a more relaxed old age alongside his wife, knowing that one day, he will will leave his children a good legacy.

loans.use: to buy stock in bulk (grains, pastas, chocolate, sweets, coffee, snacks, cakes, dairy products and other items).

loans.name: Truphosa

texts.en:
Truphosa is a lady of fifty-four years and a mother of four children. She does dairy farming and crop farming. She has been in this business for fifteen years now and gets a monthly income of seventy thousand shillings.

This will be Truphosa's sixth loan with KADET. She plans to use the entire amount to buy animal feed, fertilizer and planting seeds. In the future, Truphosa wants to be a prosperous business woman.

loans.use: to buy animal feed, fertilizer and planting seeds.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 50-year-old, married man. He has five children. He describes himself as "determined." He operates a retail shop, where he sells mobile phone accessories and also repairs mobile phones. He has been involved in this business for seven years. His business is located in a potential area, and his primary customers are of all types. He says his biggest business challenge is inadequate financing. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to his stock of mobile phone accessories. His business goal is to be financially stable, within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will excel. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to add to his stock of mobile phone accessories

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman. She has two children. 

She operates a retail stall where she sells ground nuts, paper bags, sweets, and other items. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. 

Esther will use the KES 20,000 loan to add stocks of ground nuts, sweets, and other items. Her business goal is to be successful within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance Limited (SMEP DTM).

loans.use: to add stocks of ground nuts, sweets, and other items.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a 33 year-old married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be aggressive. She operates a retail store where she sells bicycle tires, speakers, bulbs and other items. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in an area fit for business and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transport. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add stock of bicycle tires, speakers and other electronics. Her business goal is to be stable within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: add stock of bicycle tires, speakers and other electronics

loans.name: Pili

texts.en: Pili appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards by enabling her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She is requesting for a loan of Ksh. 40,000 to purchase braids, weaves, hair chemicals, hair oil, shampoos and hair conditioners for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase braids, weaves, hair chemicals, hair oil, shampoos and hair conditioners for her business

loans.name: Hovhannes

texts.en:
Hovhasnnes is from Shenavan village of Armavir region. He lives with his wife, mother and sister. Hovhannes works in the secondary school as a teacher. His wife also works in the same school. Both of them work hard to be able to earn a living.

After his father's death, Hovhannes took the responsibility of taking care of the family. The family is also engaged in breeding a livestock of cows and pigs, in the cultivation of sunflowers and several fruits (cherry, grape, apple and pear). Hovhannes currently needs a loan of USD 3000 to purchase some necessary materials for the cultivation of grapes (pipes, stones, sand and soil). He has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to the hard work during the recent times, Hovhannes was able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. 

So, he has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a poor credit history and have no access to credit products. Hovhannes and his family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them to maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase some necessary materials for cultivation of grapes (pipes, stones, sand and soil)

loans.name: Nzingo

texts.en:
Nzingo is married and has six children, all of whom go to school. She lives at her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, she has operated a green grocer shop, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high competition from other green grocers. 

With the loan that she is requesting she has wants to purchase bundles of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida is from Dalarik village of Armavir region. She lives with her two small children (seven year-old daughter and four year-old son). To take care of her small children and herself Aida works in a private bakery as a baker. However, the income that she gets is very small and is not enough to meet the needs of her family. Aida is also engaged in breeding livestock of cows and piglets to earn a living for the family. She cultivates tomatoes and grapes as well. Farming is the most important source of income for the family. Aida currently needs a loan of USD 1500 to purchase one cow, and some forage for the livestock. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to the hard work during the recent times, Aida was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Aida will be thankful to all the lenders for helping her to collect the needed loan and sustain her agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase one cow, and some forage for the livestock

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong would like to take a further loan to buy beverages to sell from her stall. Huong's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy many kinds of beverages to provide to her customers.

loans.name: Maa Gayatree Group

texts.en:
Jayanti, aged about 43 years, is the group leader of a four-member group from Ramsagarpara, Bhawanipatna of Kalahandi district, Odisha, India. She is running a tailoring workshop. Her family is comprised of three members: herself, her husband, and one son of 14 years. The member sitting in front of the sewing machine is Jayanti. Her husband helps a lot in her business to earn their livelihood. Jayanti is a very active lady who wants   some extra income out of her own efforts.

Jayanti, along with three other members of her village formed a group and it is her third loan from Mahashakti Foundation for development of their existing businesses.  At present her family income is Rs.8,000 per month which is not sufficient to manage her family and to keep pace with present-day society. 
To improve her living conditions and to earn some extra income, she wants to access a loan.  From the loan she will add a Pico machine to her workshop to bring efficiency in her stitching. She has a dream to expand her business and wants to have a shop of her own in the town.

The other three members are Jasobanti, Sandhyarani and Tribeni. They are doing vehicle painting, Brick business and vegetable vending respectively.

loans.use: to purchase a pico machine

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself as "jolly." She operates a cereals stall, where she sells maize. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in an urban area, and her primary customers are hotels and other retailers. She says her biggest business challenge is the lack of enough funds to grow the business.

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to add to her stock of maize. Her business goal is to open a maize store, within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate all her children. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to add to her stock of maize for sale

loans.name: Consolee

texts.en: Consolee is 52 years old. She is married and her husband works as a farmer. They have three children aged between twenty and twenty five. She has been in the business for the past five years. With the loan, she would like to buy more rice, sugar and beans for sale. The profits from the business will be used for making savings.

loans.use: to buy more rice, sugar and beans for sale.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe DANAYA sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques à  Médine un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur 15ème  prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme FATOUMATA fait le commerce de tissus dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle se tien en à l’extrême droite sur la photo.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt environ 7 pièces de tissus qu’elle revend en détail sur place et au marché. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 francs cfa dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the group "DANAYA" are married women, who average 38 years and four children each. The women live for the most part in monogamous families in Medine, a working-class district in Sikasso City, in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They are on their fifteenth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are concerned about meeting the needs of their customers.

Ms. FATOUMATA does commerce in cloth in this group of women. She is standing at the far right in the photo. She intends to use her loan to purchase about 7 lengths of cloth, which she sells retail locally and at the market. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used to pay back the loan with interest, and the other part goes to her savings.

loans.use: to purchase cloth

loans.name: Laurine

texts.en:
Laurine is a single woman, with one child who is underaged. They live at their own house, which has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Laurine has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, for the past two years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini-greengrocery in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Anh

texts.en: Anh would like to take another loan to buy thread and materials for increasing her production of woven products. Anh's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attracting new customers and increasing sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy thread and materials for weaving

loans.name: Maa Manikeswari Group

texts.en:
